Award.AwardTitle: Meeting: Travel Support for Diverse Early Career Scientists to Attend the 16th Congress of the International Society for Behavioral Ecology, University of Exeter, UK, 2016
Award.AbstractNarration: The 30th annual meeting of the International Society for Behavioral Ecology will be hosted by the University of Exeter, in the United Kingdom. The meeting is known for its host of renowned plenary speakers. This year will be no exception. The meeting will be opened by Richard Dawkins, with plenaries by Malte Andersson, Dorothy Cheney, Tim Clutton-Brock, Rosemary Grant, Hopi Hoekstra, Naomi Pierce & Trevor Price. In addition, attendees will present their work through talks, posters and symposia. ISBE 2016 provides a foremost opportunity for awardees to learn about and contribute to discussion of topics within behavioral ecology including: selection and conflict, social behavior, communication, behavioral plasticity, predation, foraging, parental care, and the ecology, genetics, neurobiology, and physiology of behavior. The financial assistance provided to young scientists (pre-tenure faculty, postdoctoral associates, and graduate students) will make it possible for individuals to attend who might not otherwise have been able to afford travel expenses. A committee of three United States ISBE representatives will evaluate applications for funds from young scientist participants. The committee members are committed to assuring that diversity will be enhanced at the IEC and will select a diverse group of scientists with respect to gender, career stage, and membership in groups underrepresented in science. Attendance and participation in the meeting offers a tremendous opportunity for American animal behaviorists to share their research with an international audience, interact with preeminent international researchers, meet new colleagues and to initiate new international collaborations. In addition, each travel awardee will create a "data nugget" from their own presented data or that of a conference presentation. Data nuggets are worksheets that engage K-12 students in problem-solving, graphing exercises, and data analysis using real data. With prior NSF GK12 support for the database, Data Nuggets are used in schools across the country, and are publicly available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding enabled a diverse group of 20 early career investigators based in the U.S. to attend the 16th congress of the International Society for Behavioral Ecology (ISBE 2016). Travel awards had substantial impacts on the professional development of early career behavioral ecologists. Award recipients were able to attend ISBE 2016 and present their work through talks and posters as well as network with other ISBE attendees to initiate and strengthen relationships and collaborations important for future projects and academic positions. Additionally, award recipients met to network with each other during the ISBE conference. Award recipients also developed, revised, and published educational materials (Data Nuggets). Through this process, they strengthened their abilities to communicate science to the public.

 

Our goals for this project were threefold:

(1) Empower early career investigators – Continual investment in early career scientists is necessary to sustain a productive “innovation ecosystem.” By facilitating the attendance of awardees at ISBE 2016, each scientist had ample opportunity to learn about leading-edge research and methodologies, engage in conversation with international scholars, and initiate new collaborations. Awardees also had the opportunity to meet and network with each other at ISBE 2016, which promoted connections among this diverse group of U.S.-based behavioral ecologists.

(2) Increase diversity – Diverse perspectives come from diverse individuals, and these perspectives are necessary to transform the frontiers of science. To reach a broad, diverse group of scientists, the travel award opportunity was advertised broadly through community and society listservs, personal communication with researchers at minority serving institutions, and social media. From the applications, we prioritized early career researchers with limited access to travel funding. To increase the diversity of U.S. attendees, we selected diverse awardees with respect to gender, race, membership and/or mentorship in underrepresented groups, and career stage. 

(3) Improve science education resources – A scientifically literate society is vital to effectively confront national and global issues from climate change to public health. Award recipients adapted their own research into a “Data Nugget” for use in K-12 science classrooms. Collectively, we produced eleven (11) Data Nuggets that are or will soon be available at http://datanuggets.org. Data Nuggets are worksheets that teach quantitative and evidence-based reasoning to K-12 students. Data Nuggets offer K-12 students the opportunity to interact with current scientific data, improving their quantitative reasoning and critical thinking skills. They also connect scientists with K-12 students and teachers. These educational products developed by award recipients will improve the public understanding of science through the production of broadly distributed K-12 science education resources. In fact, the Data Nuggets produced by award recipients are currently being used by K-12 teachers in Michigan.

 

Additional outcomes of this project include:

(1) an invited review paper co-authored by six of the award recipients, and

(2) a successfully funded NSF supplemental grant to one award recipient as a result of a collaboration initiated at ISBE 2016 that will support mentoring of ethnic minorities and first-generation college women to conduct research.
